summary: This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy manual section detailing the elements of prohibited acts for inmates, categorizing offenses by severity (Greatest, High, Moderate, Low Moderate) and providing definitions for each offense code. It outlines the required components (subject, time, location, act, victim) to prove a violation and serves as an internal regulatory guide for prison staff.
keyFacts: The document is a BOP policy manual effective November 18, 2020, defining prohibited acts for inmates.
It categorizes offenses into four severity levels: Greatest (100-series), High (200-series), Moderate (300-series), and Low Moderate (400-series).
It specifies that to prove a prohibited act, staff must establish elements including the subject (inmate), time, location, act, and victim (if applicable).
The act is described as the most significant element and the one that presents the most problems in definition.
Offense codes cover a wide range of behaviors from killing (Code 100) and sexual assault (Codes 114, 229) to lesser infractions like being untidy (Code 330) or using abusive language (Code 404).
